key_points: Kyle Rittenhouse's attorney seeks to argue one victim was a sex offender aiming to steal Rittenhouse's gun.
Attorney Mark Richards claims Joseph Rosenbaum started the altercation to take Rittenhouse’s firearm, reinforcing the self-defense claim.
Kimberley Motley, representing Rosenbaum’s estate, disputes Richards' theory, asserting Rittenhouse was the aggressor.
Motion filed to dismiss gun possession charge against Rittenhouse, arguing Wisconsin law doesn’t apply to his rifle type.
Rittenhouse, now 18, was charged with multiple counts, including reckless homicide and being a minor in possession of a dangerous weapon.
Rittenhouse had traveled to Kenosha from Illinois amid protests over the police shooting of Jacob Blake.
Prosecutors want to introduce evidence of Rittenhouse's prior alleged violent conduct and links to far-right group Proud Boys.
Richards contends the prior altercation and Proud Boys association are irrelevant to the case.
The incident has polarized opinions, painting Rittenhouse either as a white supremacist or a gun rights symbol.
A hearing on the motions is scheduled for Sept. 17, with Rittenhouse's trial set to begin on Nov. 1.
spokespersons: Kimberley Motley (Attorney representing Joseph Rosenbaum’s estate)
